zeroCase.description: Bring your location data to CARTO so that you can visualise it and start predicting key insights. Learn about importing your data here.

emptyCase.onlyShared: No maps here. Go to the maps shared with you.

SolutionsPage.solutionsDescription: Consolidating your site network? Need to reduce fleet costs? Redesigning your sales territories? Answer your question through the lens of location.
SolutionsPage.talkUsDescription: Our account management team will give you a firsthand view and discuss with you how we can help your organization to do the same.

sitePlanning.title: Site Planning
sitePlanning.description: Drive site selection and investment decisions with always-on data streams, enabling more accurate revenue prediction and reduced risk of failed location decisions.

territoryManagement.title: Territory Management
territoryManagement.description: Design and align sales and service territories to increase productivity and reduce costs using spatial field operations data.

logisticsOptimization.title: Logistics Optimization
logisticsOptimization.description: Harness the power of geospatial to optimize your Supply Chain, enabling a smarter, more efficient operation.

cartovl.title: Develop an interactive custom web map
cartovl.subtitle: Develop impressive interactive maps and use them on your websites and apps.

step1.title: Develop an interactive web map
step1.text1: Our platform provides a set of libraries and APIs to develop our own customizable and interactive maps. CARTO VL is a JavaScript library to developer beautiful interactive web maps.
step1.text2: In this guide, you will learn how to load the library in your project, create a map with one of our basemaps, and add a data layer.
step1.text3: Interested in other libraries or APIs? Visit our Developer Center.

summary.text: Create an HTML file with this template that loads CARTO VL and Mapbox GL libraries.

howto.instruction1: Create an HTML file and add the following scripts to your <head> element.

extras.resource1: CARTO VL is our more advanced rendering library and it’s constantly adding new features. You can learn what cool stuff did we add lately in our Product Updates blog.
extras.resource2: You can also install and load CARTO VL using npm.

step3.summary: Define the <div> element that will contain your map

howto.instruction1: Define the <div> element that will contain the map in the <body> of your file. The map, layers and controls will be displayed in this element:
howto.instruction2: Paste the following CSS code in the bottom of the <head> element to define some basic styles for the map:

step4.summary: Create a MapboxGL map with one of our basemaps.

howto.instruction1: Add this script below your <div> container to load the map:

extras.resource1: CARTO VL relies on Mapbox GL to render basemaps. Choose between carto.basemaps.voyager, carto.basemaps.positron, and carto.basemaps.darkmatter basemaps.

step5.summary: Connect to a test CARTO account and add a data layer to your map

howto.instruction1: Connect to a CARTO account by specifiying the username and API key you want to use. In this case, we're using a test account and a test access key.
howto.instruction2: Now that CARTO VL has access to the account you can create and add layers to display any of the datasets on that account and add them to the map.

extras.resource1: Want to use your own account? Learn about API Authorization.

congrats.title: Congratulations!
congrats.message1: You've just created your first map with CARTO VL!

extras.resource1: Learn more with the following examples from our Developer Center.

card1.title: Style features by category
card1.subtitle: Learn how to change the style of the features by a given column

card2.title: Add hover popups
card2.subtitle: Learn how to display info about a feature when user mouses over it.

card3.title: Animate the features
card3.subtitle: Learn how to animate the features of the map by different columns.

cartoframes.title: Add spatial data to your data science workflow
cartoframes.subtitle: Integrate spatial data into your data science models using our Python library.

step1.summary: Integrate spatial analysis in your Python scripts
step1.text1: CARTOframes is a Python library that allows data scientists to integrate spatial analysis in their workflows. It integrates seemingly with Jupyter Notebooks and GeoPandas.
step1.text2: In this guide, you will learn how to connect to a CARTO account, list and explore datasets, and create a basic interactive map in a Jupyter notebook.
step1.text3: Interested in other libraries or APIs? Visit our Developer Center.

howto.instruction1: Install CARTOframes with pip. Simply type the following in the command in your terminal.
howto.instruction2: Install Jupyter Notebook with pip. Type the following comand in your terminal.
howto.instruction3: Start Jupyter Notebook. Type the following command in your terminal.

extras.resource1: There are other ways to install CARTOframes. Read more here.

step3.summary: Import cartoframes package and connect to CARTO account using a username and API key.

howto.instruction1: Use cartoframes.Credentials to connect to a CARTO account. In this example, we’re using a test account and a test access key.

extras.resource1: Want to use your own account? Learn about API Authorization here.

step4.summary: List all of the available sample datasets including the examples example_context account.

howto.instruction1: List all of the available tables using the example_context:

step5.summary: Read one of the sample datasets into a pandas DataFrame

howto.instruction1: Read and list the first rows of one of the sample datasets.

step6.summary: Visualize a sample dataset as a choropleth map

howto.instruction1: Import the Layer class to visualize a dataset as an interactive map and pass it as an argument to the map. We can go further by styling by the poverty_per_pop column to visualize based on a numeric value.

extras.resource1: Interactive maps only display in Jupyter notebooks. Use the interactive=False map option to get a static version.

congrats.title: Congratulations!
congrats.message1: You've just created your first Jupyter Notebook with CARTOframes!

extras.resource1: Learn more with the following examples from our Developer Center.

card2.title: CARTOframes with GeoPandas
card2.subtitle: Learn how to use CARTOframes with GeoPandas

card3.title: Using CARTOframes to explore the Citibike system
card3.subtitle: Learn how to process data from Citibike, upload it to your account, and create some maps

builder.title: Create a web map from your browser
builder.subtitle: Uncover insights from your location data with our online drag and drop tool.

step1.title: Build a map with our drag & drop editor
step1.text1: Builder is our drag & drop tool to design, build and publish interactive web maps with your location data. Maps can be easily shared or embedded on any website or blog.
step1.text2: In this guide, you will learn how to upload a .csv file and create your first dataset, create a simple map, and publish it.

howto.instruction2: Visit the Data page and click the “New Dataset” button
howto.instruction3: In the Connect dataset section click Browse, select the file, and click “Connect dataset”

extras.resource1: You can also import your data by dragging and dropping your files into your dashboard

summary.text: Explore your new dataset and understand the different options

howto.instruction1: Navigate through your new dataset. From here, you can add, remove, rename, and change the type of your columns. You can also edit each value and even run SQL queries.

summary.text: Create a new map with the dataset you just created, publish it and share it

howto.instruction1: Double click on the name of the map (Untitled Map) and rename it to “My first map”
howto.instruction2: Click on the red privacy button to make your map “Public”
howto.instruction4: Copy the link or embed code of your map and share it with the world!

extras.resource1: You can add more layers to your map by clicking “Add new layer”

congrats.title: Congratulations!
congrats.message1: You've just created your first web map using Builder

extras.resource1: Learn more with the following examples from our Help Center.

card1.title: Understanding map layers in Builder
card1.subtitle: Learn how to add data layers to your maps, style them, and more.

card2.title: Customizing Pop-Ups with HTML
card2.subtitle: Learn how to setup and customise popups with HTML.

card3.title: Exploring Data with Widgets
card3.subtitle: Learn how to add interactive widgets to explore your data.
